passages.text: Australia | Metals & Mining
Equity Research August 28, 2025

Dynamic and rapidly improved market dynamics have positioned Lynas with an opportunity to secure its growth profile out to 2030 via an underwritten \(\) 750m\(placement and\) \ \(75m\) SPP. Securing strategic new offtakes or downstream partnerships should support current valuation, LYC looks well positioned via production growth and diversification to achieve this. That said, we think the stock is pricing in much of the upside. We downgrade to HOLD (from Buy), PT AUD12.50.

Rare earths market rebalancing continues. As the rare earth industry enters its traditional peak consumption season, an increase in downstream demand is driving up procurement. Ongoing geopolitical intervention in the REE market, as evidenced by China's MIIT Quantity Control announced on Fri 22- Aug, and the US DoD agreement with MP, are continuing to drive rapid NdPr price appreciation.

2030 and beyond. Lynas has outlined a three- pronged growth strategy: 1) Add resource & scale; 2) Increase downstream capacity; and 3) Expand into non- China metal & magnet supply chains. To support this, it is undertaking an \(\) 750m\(underwritten placement plus\) \ \(75m\) SPP. There appears to be flexibility in the Uses of Cash, allowing Lynas to pursue acquisitive growth if opportunities arise. That said, we cannot yet quantify earnings growth from this strategy. Key missing data points to assess capital returns include: ionic colony volumes, grade and economics; magnet factory capex, margin, equity needs; and Samarimu/Yttrium volumes and production costs.

FY25 Results - Underlying EBITDA of \(\) 101m\(was a slight beat to our (10%) and V\Ae (2%) expectations (Figure 2). No final dividend aligned with our expectations. Closing cash of\) \ \(167m\) was pre- released, supported by OpCF of \(\) 104m\(, with\) \ \(431m\) spent on major projects.

Operational updates & FY26 outlook. Modifications at LAMP over FY25 are expected to expand production from 9.0kpta to 10.5kpta, with 1.5kpta separated Dy, Tb & Ho in FY26. We forecast FY26 at 8.4kt NdPr vs VAE of 8.9kt. Kalgoorlie MREC should stabilise lanthanide dependence, although with \(\alpha\) MREC volumes disclosed, we assume focus remains on stabilising output and improving quality. Mt Weld Stage 2 expansion is expected to commence commissioning in 1Q26 supported by cutback 5, and dual concentrate streams from cracking/ leaching. Seadrift (US) is looking increasingly unlikely to proceed and will likely be replaced by increased Heavie capacity at Malaysia.

Following a near doubling of its share price in the prior month, we downgrade to HOLD, from Buy, on valuation grounds. Our PT remains unchanged at AUD12.50. While we acknowledge the potential for further government intervention in the sector, which would be supportive of earnings upside and decrease the equity risk premium of the stock, we see the stock as full on valuation grounds.
Please see analyst certifications, important disclosure information, and information regarding the status of non-Us analysts on pages 7 - 12 of this report. \\* Jefferies (Australia) Pty Ltd

Lynas is the only producer of separated rare earth oxides of scale outside China. And the only producer of Heavy Rare Earths. Geopolitically, it is an important, distinctive company. It has a world- class resource base, strong customer relationships, an extensive growth pipeline, and a lengthy track record of success. Highlighting its geopolitical importance, the US Dept of Defense is funding a new LYC separation facility in the US.
Risk/Reward - 12 Month View

Our base case valuation incorporates further downstream capacity expansions, including the announced HRE/LRE facility in the US, as well as expansions at LAMP beyond that currently planned by the company. This should ultimately ensure fuller utilisation of its upstream capacity post construction of the KREPF.
We set our target based on a blend of NPV \((50\%)\) and FY27E EV/EBITDA and P/OpCF multiples.

Top Material Issue(s): Key issues for the sector include the consideration of net zero targets, actions being taken to reduce emissions and achieve other set goals, relationships with traditional owners of the land on which mines are located, waste management, and workforce safety.

Company Targets: ESG targets include 1) \(40\%\) of employees and leadership being female, 2) zero harm, 3) implement opportunities to reduce scope 1 and scope 2 emissions, 4) maximise local and regional employment and provide support and opportunities for local communities.

Qs to Mgmt: 1) What are your climate related goals, and how are you seeking to achieve them? 2) Who are the traditional owners of the land on which you operate and what are your interactions with them? 3) What are the key community concerns at your operations and how have you addressed them? 4) What are your considerations about paying a 'fair' rent in the countries in which you operate achieving an appropriate return on capital? 5) How are management incentivised to deliver sustainability goals?
Our downside scenario assumes no improvement in RE commodity prices from the early 2024 lows as China continues to control the market through continuing to expand its own domestic supply.
Production ramp- up: Ramp- up of production at new Kalgoorie RE processing facility & recently expanded separation facility in Malaysia; delivering to plan would be positive.
Expansion pot': Co has latent capacity within its ops which could be matched by further downstream capacity additions.
RE mkt: After ongoing mt softness from weak demand and ongoing Chinese supply influencing pricing, we expect geopolitical influences to increase RE support over 2025.
Figure 5 - REE Pricing
Source:Jefferies, Bloomberg

On Friday, 22 August, China's Ministry of Industry and Information Technology (MIIT) released guidelines on the interim measures for Total Quality Control and Management of Rare Earth Mining and Smelting Separation. Below is the translated version of the release.
The original version, in Mandarin Chinese, is available at www.miit.gov.cn.

1. These measures aim to strengthen the total quantity control and management of rare earth mining and smelting separation, based on the Mineral Resources Law of the People's Republic of China, the Rare Earth Management Regulations, and other relevant laws and regulations.  
2. Rare Earth Mining refers to the extraction and beneficiation of various rare earth ores such as bastnaesite, ion-type rare earth ores, and mixed rare earth ores to produce rare earth mineral products. Rare Earth Smelting and Separation refers to the processing of rare earth mineral products into various single or mixed rare earth oxides, salts, and other compounds.  
3. The state implements total quantity control over rare earth mining and smelting separation, including products obtained through mining, imports, and processing of other minerals (e.g., monazite concentrates).  
4. The Ministry of Industry and Information Technology (MIIT), in coordination with the Ministry of Natural Resources (MNR) and the National Development and Reform Commission (NDRC), oversees national quota management. Local governments above the county level are responsible for implementing these controls within their jurisdictions.  
5. MIIT, MNR, and NDRC set annual quota targets based on national economic goals, resource reserves, industry development, ecological protection, and market demand. These are submitted to the State Council for approval.  
6. MIIT and the Ministry of Natural Resources allocate quotas to rare earth producers based on production capacity, technical level, and environmental and safety standards. These quotas are communicated to provincial and local authorities.  
7. Rare earth production enterprises must strictly comply with laws, administrative regulations, and relevant national provisions, and engage in rare earth mining and smelting separation within the scope of the total quantity control indicators. Only enterprises designated by MIIT and the Ministry of Natural Resources may engage in rare earth mining and smelting separation. Other organizations or individuals are prohibited from engaging in these activities.  
8. Rare earth production enterprises shall be responsible for the implementation status of their enterprise's total quantity control indicators.

9. Rare earth production enterprises shall promptly submit the monthly and annual implementation status of the total quantity control indicators to the competent departments of industry and information technology and natural resources of the county-level people's government where they are located.

10. The competent departments of industry and information technology and natural resources of the people's governments at or above the county level shall summarize the monthly and annual implementation status of the total quantity control indicators of rare earth production enterprises within their administrative region, and promptly submit it to the competent departments of industry and information technology and natural resources of the next higher-level people's government.

11. Rare earth production enterprises shall establish a record system for the flow direction of rare earth products, truthfully record the flow direction information of rare earth products, and before the 10th of each month, input the flow direction information of rare earth products from the previous month into the rare earth product traceability information system established by the Ministry of Industry and Information Technology in conjunction with relevant departments.

12. Rare earth production enterprises shall fulfill the obligations of network and data security protection, establish and improve the internal network and data security management system of the enterprise, enhance the level of network and data security protection of the enterprise, and ensure the network and data security of the enterprise.

13. The competent departments of industry and information technology and natural resources of the people's governments at or above the county level shall strengthen supervision and inspection of the implementation status of total quantity control indicators and other matters, investigate and deal with illegal acts according to law, strictly implement the provisions and requirements of laws, administrative regulations, and the State Council regarding administrative inspections involving enterprises, and ensure that supervision and inspection are based on law, strictly standardized, fair and civilized, precise and efficient.

14. The competent departments of industry and information technology and natural resources of the people's governments at or above the county level shall promptly report the handling of illegal acts to the competent departments of industry and information technology and natural resources of the next higher-level people's government.

15. The competent departments of industry and information technology and natural resources of the provincial people's government shall, before the end of December each year, report the overall situation of supervision and inspection of total quantity control indicators within their administrative region to the Ministry of Industry and Information Technology and the Ministry of Natural Resources.

16. Rare earth production enterprises that violate the provisions of these Measures, or refuse or obstruct the supervision and inspection departments from performing their supervision and inspection duties according to law, shall be ordered to make corrections by the competent departments of industry and information technology and natural resources of the people's governments at or above the county level according to the division of responsibilities, and be punished in accordance with the provisions of the Mineral Resources Law of the People's Republic of China, the Rare Earth Management Regulations, and other laws and administrative regulations.

17. Rare earth production enterprises that violate the provisions of these Measures and are subject to administrative penalties shall have their total quantity control indicators for the next year reduced.

18. Staff of the competent departments of industry and information technology, natural resources, and development and reform who abuse their power, neglect their duties, or engage in favoritism and fraud in the work of total quantity control management of rare earth mining and smelting separation shall be punished according to law.

19. Violations of the provisions of these Measures that constitute acts violating public security management shall be subject to public security management penalties according to law; those constituting crimes shall be investigated for criminal responsibility according to law.

20. These Measures shall come into effect from the date of publication. The Notice on Printing and Distributing the Interim Measures for the Management of Rare Earth Directive Production Plans (MIIT Original [2012] No. 285), published by the Ministry of Industry and Information Technology on June 13, 2012, shall be repealed simultaneously.
Source: Chinese Ministry of Industry and Information Technology, Jefferies.

Lynas Rare Earths (LYC ASX) is a producer of rare earths materials. It is the only significant producer of separated rare earths outside of China. It's Mt Weld mine in WA, Australia hosts a world- class rare earths orebody, underpinning the company's downstream production located at its new cracking and leaching facility in Kalgoorlie, WA, as well as its established separation facility in Malaysia. LYC is also establishing a presence in rare earths processing in the US with funding support from the US Department of Defense. We believe LYC is positioned as a global leader in a geopolitically sensitive commodity.

Our base case valuation incorporates further downstream capacity expansions, including the announced at the HRE/LRE facility in the US, as well as expansions at LAMP beyond that currently planned by the company. This will ultimately ensure fuller utilisation of its upstream capacity post construction of the KREPF. We set our target based on a blend of NPV (50%) and FY27 EV/EBITDA and P/OpCF multiples.

- Movements in rare earths prices will have a material impact on cash flows, earnings and sentiment towards the company.- Operational issues can result in production losses that can materially impact our forecasts.- Cost inflation has been a key factor in Australia in particular and remains a risk to the earnings outlook.- Delays or capital cost increases to expansion projects in Australia, Malaysia and the US can have an impact on FCF generation and the earnings profile.- Risks around regulatory approvals and licences are a factor in Malaysia in particular where ability to process concentrates from Australia is granted under an exception to its licence which expires in March 2026.- Supply is a key risk to rare earths markets, arising primarily from the potential for ongoing supply growth from China. In addition, over the medium to longer term, there are a number of proposed projects globally that may add to global supply if successful. Our base case view is many projects will struggle given the technical challenges in processing rare earths.- On the demand side, any deterioration in the outlook for EV penetration rates on wind installations will slow the recovery in rare earth prices.

but various regulations may prevent us from doing so. Aside from certain industry reports published on a periodic basis, the large majority of reports are published at irregular intervals as appropriate in the analyst's judgement.
(Article 3(1)e and Article 7 of MAR) Recommendation Published Recommendation Distributed

Buy - Describes securities that we expect to provide a total return (price appreciation plus yield) of \(15\%\) or more within a 12- month period. Hold - Describes securities that we expect to provide a total return (price appreciation plus yield) of plus \(15\%\) or minus \(10\%\) within a 12- month period. Underperform - Describes securities that we expect to provide a total return (price appreciation plus yield) of minus \(10\%\) or less within a 12- month period. The expected total return (price appreciation plus yield) for Buy rated securities with an average security price consistently below \(\) 10\(is 20\%\) or more within a 12- month period as these companies are typically more volatile than the overall stock market. For Hold rated securities with an average security price consistently below\) \ \(10\) , the expected total return (price appreciation plus yield) is plus or minus \(20\%\) within a 12- month period. For Underperform rated securities with an average security price consistently below \(\) 10\(, the expected total return (price appreciation plus yield) is minus\) 20\% \(or less within a 12- month period.
NR - The investment rating and price target have been temporarily suspended. Such suspensions are in compliance with applicable regulations and/or Jefferies policies.
CS - Coverage Suspended. Jefferies has suspended coverage of this company.
NC - Not covered. Jefferies does not cover this company.

Restricted - Describes issuers where, in conjunction with Jefferies engagement in certain transactions, company policy or applicable securities regulations prohibit certain types of communications, including investment recommendations.
Monitor - Describes securities whose company fundamentals and financials are being monitored, and for which no financial projections or opinions on the investment merits of the company are provided.

Jefferies' methodology for assigning ratings may include the following: market capitalization, maturity, growth/value, volatility and expected total return over the next 12 months. The price targets are based on several methodologies, which may include, but are not restricted to, analyses of market risk, growth rate, revenue stream, discounted cash flow (DCF), EBITDA, EPS, cash flow (CF), free cash flow (FCF), EV/EBITDA, P/E, PE/growth, P/CF, P/FCF, premium (discount)/average group EV/EBITDA, premium (discount)/average group P/E, sum of the parts, net asset value, dividend returns, and return on equity (ROE) over the next 12 months.

Jefferies Franchise Picks include stock selections from among the best stock ideas from our equity analysts over a 12 month period. Stock selection is based on fundamental analysis and may take into account other factors such as analyst conviction, differentiated analysis, a favorable risk/reward ratio and investment themes that Jefferies analysts are recommending. Jefferies Franchise Picks will include only Buy rated stocks and the number can vary depending on analyst recommendations for inclusion. Stocks will be added as new opportunities arise and removed when the reason for inclusion changes, the stock has met its desired return, if it is no longer rated Buy and/or if it triggers a stop loss. Stocks having 120 day volatility in the bottom quartile of S&P stocks will continue to have a \(15\%\) stop loss, and the remainder will have a \(20\%\) stop. Franchise Picks are not intended to represent a recommended portfolio of stocks and is not sector based, but we may note where we believe a Pick falls within an investment style such as growth or value.

As a result, investors should be aware that Jefferies may have a conflict of interest that could affect the objectivity of this report. Investors should consider this report as only a single factor in making their investment decision.
